Award.AwardTitle: Improving Students' Professional Communication Skills By Employing an Integrated System of Learning Tools and Methods

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on creating and deploying an integrated system of components to facilitate the learning of communication skills within engineering courses. The design of the components is guided by the need to provide every student in an engineering program the opportunity to learn technical and professional communication skills while requiring minimal changes in existing curricula and instructional resource allocations. The project's working hypothesis is that this approach - combined with thorough evaluation efforts that measure the effectiveness of the learning system, and the dissemination of project efforts online and in workshops - will lead to the development of a research-informed instructional framework and ultimately lead to a significant improvement in the communications skills of engineering students.

Communication skills are critical to engineers' professional success. Nevertheless many engineering programs are faced with various challenges that cause them to struggle to prepare their students to meet the communication expectations of the workplace. One challange is that communication courses are typically taught to small cohorts, providing a small number of students with the individualized instruction that they need. This approach is also problematic because it requires the employment of numerous instructors to address the communication needs of whole engineering programs. The number of engineering courses that students are required to take presents another challenge to programs. It leaves little curricular space to add the multiple communication courses that students need to gain the skills that are critical to their professional success, which range from writing in different genres to oral presentations and visual communication. One approach is to embed communication pedagogy and writing instructors in existing engineering courses. But, this is a costly approach to maintain and does not provide instructors the time they need to teach component skills. Thus, the challenge of finding more efficient ways to teach engineering students the full range of effective communication skills that they need to achieve professional success still exists.

This project explores the challenge by developing and evaluating a system of distributed communication learning components that are designed by the Carnegie Mellon engineering community and a writing instructor in engineering courses. The system integrates human instruction with online tutorials and references as supplemental learning components. The instruction evolves from initial reliance on writing tasks where interaction between instructors and students is important, to a gradual reduction of contact between instructors and students. In the early (novice) stages, students work with a writing instructor who guides them through the acquisition, practice, and application of component skills using online tutorials and references, which is the focus of the first phase of this project. As students become mature communicators, they increasingly participate in peer-review activities where they become engaged in giving and receiving critiques with their peers - a common practice in the workplace, which would be the focus of this project in future phases.

Introduction

Communication skills are widely recognized as critical to engineers’ professional success. However, many engineering programs face logistical realities that hamper their ability to help students become effective technical communicators. This exploratory project aims to provide every engineering student the opportunity to learn technical communication concepts through an integrated system of learning resources, including a writing instructor, engineering instructor, peer tutors, friends, a campus writing center, and online tutorials. Our goal is to develop a working model of an integrated system of learning resources that can improve engineering students’ writing skills while optimizing the cost of instruction and resource development.

Goals

At Carnegie Mellon University, collaborators in Engineering, English, and Design piloted a study that aimed to understand how engineering students used an integrated system of learning resources in the context of a junior-level Civil and Environmental Engineering course. In particular, we were interested in examining our hypothesis that well-designed online learning tutorials that allow students to review basic communication skills would lighten the workload of instructors. To test our hypothesis, we developed a series of online technical communication learning tutorials, consisting of 18 video lessons and 90 multiple choice and revision activities. The online tutorials supplement rather than supplant the course’s embedded writing instructor, add to the existing palette of resources available to students, and are presented to students as just-in-time, self-study aids to their drafting and revision processes for major assignments. Through this combined approach, we have aimed to explore the strengths and limitations of integrated, digital/human writing instruction techniques for engineering classrooms.

In 2013 and 2014, the online tutorials were made available as self-learning resources in the junior level Environmental Engineering course, and usage data and writing samples were collected to understand to what extent students improve their communication skills. We also conducted surveys to find out how students used various components in the system of learning resources, and their attitude toward those resources.

Results

We observed that most students do not take advantage of self-learning resources to improve their writing. Additional student interviews were conducted to further explore the factors that influence students’ motivations to use self-learning resources; results suggest students’ preference for resources that are (a) deemed relevant to their individual and immediate learning needs (i.e., related to instructor feedback on a specific assignment),  and (b) easy to access. We subsequently developed a PDF-based interactive rubric, which embedded personalized hyperlinks to lessons related to specific feedback the student received from the instructor. Results indicate that although the interactive pdf increased traffic to the online tutorials, most students prefer to use the instructor’s in-line comments as a just-in-time revision strategy.
